Award.AwardTitle: Soliton Dynamics in Mid-Infrared Quantum-Cascade Lasers

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this program is to investigate the soliton dynamics in mid-infrared quantum-cascade lasers. The soliton effect originates in the cancellation between the group velocity dispersion and self-phase modulation. Such effect may play a key role in the generation of ultra-short pulses by mid-infrared quantum-cascade lasers, which are important to major applications such as biomedical sensing and environmental control. The elucidation of the underlying physics may therefore enable a new class of compact ultrafast lasers in the mid-infrared region since group velocity dispersion and self-phase modulation are simultaneously present in the same structure and are both associated with the intersubband transitions in quantum-cascade lasers.

The intellectual merit is that the proposed research will make significant contributions to the understanding of ultrafast dynamics in quantum cascade lasers. Such devices are of intense interest for mid-infrared and far-infrared continuous-wave as well as for short-pulsed sources. The transformative of this research is that results from the investigation could be applied to design a new type of quantum cascade laser medium yielding shortened mid-infrared pulses through bandgap engineering. The design will be pursued through the collaboration with an experimental group.

The broader impacts are in providing excellent multidisciplinary training in the area of nanophotonics within a research environment. Two Master?s students are expected to participate in this research. This program will also provide training opportunities for local K-12 teachers and high-school students through workshops. The results from the proposed research will be published in the scientific and engineering literature and presented at conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes on Intellectual Merit

Through investigating laser pulse progression under the simultaneous existence of various physics phenomena in quantum-cascade lasers, a new type of nanoscale laser devices, we advanced the understanding of the unique dynamic behavior of quantum-cascade lasers and the interplay among those physics effects. The novelty of this work lies in that we well accounted all major effects in a QCL gain medium, while some of these effects were missed in previous discussions in the literature. Theoretical results are correlated with experimental results published.

Results tell that quantum-cascade lasers have very different dynamic behavior compared to traditional semiconductor lasers and optical fibers. Results could provide design guidelines of QCLs for stable pulse emission and frequency combs generation in mid-infrared region, which is of great and growing interest for applications such as biomedical and chemical sensing and free-space communications. The biomedical sensing techniques can provide inexpensive, reliable and accurate medical diagnosis for human beings. The chemical sensing technology is crucial to the environmental pollution control and thus the health-related quality of human life. The free-space communication is an economic and convenient way of telecommunication and computer networking, which closely relates to human’s daily life.

Thus, our study not only promotes the physics insights on nanoscale optical devices, but also provides new design principles of such devices for various applications based on the elucidations of new physics complications.

Outcomes on Broader Impacts

Broader impacts of this research exhibit as training graduate students, promoting the science and engineering education in local community, and broadly disseminating research results to related research field.

The PI’s institute is a Master-level university without PhD program. Three Master’s (MS) students have been supported by this program, with one student performing thesis research for two years and two students on short-term project research. The PI’s working with these students includes both research and teaching components. As most MS students lack independence, step-by-step guidance is deserved in advising.  The student working on thesis-based research successfully graduated with a Master’s degree in Electrical Engineering. The other two students conducted short-term project-based research under this program. Through this program, these students not only advanced their technical understanding on topics related to this project, but also received training on research methodology through working with the PI. At the same time, the PI also enhanced her experience on advising MS students and advanced her career not only as a good researcher, but also as a good teacher and advisor.

The PI was also engaged in connecting this program to local community through various opportunities. The PI has been invited to give several seminar talks to freshmen engineering students. In these talks, the PI introduced the application, design consideration and performance features of quantum-cascade lasers. For most students, this was their first opportunity to really learn some details about a type of nanoscale devices. These talks serve to raise local college students’ interest in nanotechnology as well as the connection between their major engineering disciplines and nanotechnology. The PI volunteered as a key personnel in the organizing committee of a Girl’s Camp held by her department.  Participants of the camp were local high school female students. The goal of this camp is to improve the participation and diversity of local students in the field of science and engineering.  Also, the PI representing her department presented at an education event (the STEAM educator conference) held by the local community. The conference offered an opportunity for local STEM educators to learn and explore scientific and engineering knowledge through demonstrations and presentations by university STEM faculty members. It helps enhance the connection between local k-12 schools and universities and promote the interests in science and engineering of local communities.   All such effort helps provide the science and engineering training in the local community and enhance the outreach of the PI’s institution to local teachers and students.

Results from this research have been disseminated in high quality journals and conferences. So far, two journal papers have been published, and another two journal papers have been prepared and will be submitted soon. Results have been presented at 5 conferences. Another conference abstract is accepted and will be presented in January 2017.
